entry.title: Combined summary - Preventing MITM - Providing new nodes with real pubkeys
entry.summary: The Lightning Network is a decentralized network of payment channels that provides faster and cheaper bitcoin transactions. It works through IOUs and HTLCs that can be spent on the blockchain or a pegged sidechain. However, there are concerns about the security of the Lightning network. The discussion focuses on how an attacker can join the network and open channels with nodes to commit vandalism. It's argued that the probability of finding at least one good node when joining the Lightning network is about 1-(V/T)^N. To mitigate this risk, people who want to join the network are advised to select a friend or someone they trust to route their payments. The conversation also examines other forms of attacks such as Sybil attacks and pervasive attacks. Sybil attacks can create fake edges in the routing graph, while in pervasive attack scenarios, everyone in a large group would simultaneously suffer from a sybil attack.To test the authenticity of the Lightning network, one can pay 1 satoshi to merchants (or friends) and set the R value as the (double) SHA256 of the decrypted onion message. This test ensures that routes are legitimate and payments go through. The cost of forwarding a single transaction is around 2.4e-8 dollars, which is currently about 9.1e-11 bitcoin, which is 0.0091 satoshi. Lightning balances are denominated in millisatoshi, so as long as yours increases by 9 or 10, you're doing fine.
